intro: Matelea altamirana, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its large, showy white flowers that open at night. The plant produces a milky sap that contains toxic alkaloids, making it potentially harmful to humans and animals. Its leaves are typically heart-shaped and have a velvety texture, while its stems are woody and branching. Matelea altamirana thrives in arid or semi-arid environments and is often found in rocky soils.
